bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 30, 1953

div1.p: Truby discusses the Camp Lazear National Monument and Nogueira's efforts in establishing the monument. Truby expresses his displeasure at the inaccuracies in an article about “Finlay Field.”

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 30, 1953
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
January 30, 1953
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I was very much impressed with your long letter describing the
dedication of the “Camp Lazear National Monument” and the other
functions of December 3 in Havana. I was impressed too with the
fine layout of the little park, especially the beautiful white
limestone wall with the medallions and placques. What a fine
little memorial it can become with a little attention by someone
like Dr. Nogueira! What a wonderful job he really has done in
laying the foundation of a fitting little shrine, such as you
have visualized and which will be forthcoming if both countries
cooperate. The thousands of visitors to Cuba during the winter
season will want to see that historical place because everybody
seems to be interested in our episode of yellow fever at Camp
Lazear.

The floral tributes were wonderful and I was sorry that I did not
inquire about them and manage to get the University of Pennsylvania
in on it also with the University of Virginia and so many other
institutions.

I was delighted to hear that “Louiseta” Wood was present and I
like the way she seems to have stolen the show. She can do much
to help you in your work down there as the Cuban people simply
adored the General and his family, and evidently that feeling for
the family still exists. I wonder if you happened to mention my
name to her? I was the Surgeon at Governors Island, N. Y., while
General Wood was in command and I was their family physician, but
as everyone in the family was so strong and healthy, I had very
few calls from them. However, “Louiseta”, as we all called her in
those days was at one time quite sick with a respiratory infection.
So I think she will probably remember me and my family. Her mother
died just prior to the publication of my book which I very much
wanted her to see. If I had an extra copy I would certainly send
it to Miss Wood. I will keep my eyes open for one to send her.
I think I was the first one to really point out how little the
public really knew how important his help was to the success of
Reed's work.

I have heard nothing from the Cubans re my medal but your statement
makes it clear that it was actually awarded. I was hoping that
they would notify me officially but as it did not come, I thought
it wise to send Pedro copies of the four letter that I wrote to
various Cuban officials and asked him to set me straight with them.
Which letter was received by them I do not know. I expected to
express my thanks upon some official notification from the Cuban
Government. Of course, I want you to know how much I have
appreciated all your efforts, for I feel that you and Dr. Nogueira
had much to do with getting my name before the Cuban officials.
Possibly my book helped, but I doubt if they had many copies.

I am enclosing a copy of the remarks made in the Military Surgeon
about the dedication of “Finlay Field.” It was such a short,
inaccurate, and imcomplete account that I thought you ought to
see it. Someone should see that the Medical officers of the
services get a full account of the story by receiving a more
factual and interesting account of this ceremony. Photos of
the medallions and readable ones of the two placques should
appear as illustrations.

I have been slow in writing you because of several reasons. First,
I have to spend most of my time developing my muscles and this
takes it out of me so much that I am quite used up by afternoon
every day. The holidays and everything else have increased my
correspondence so that I can hardly keep up with it. But, things
are going well with me and I am really making progress. These
lesions of nerve tissues make recovery very long since the accompany-
ing atrophy of the muscles has to be redeveloped by real work. I
have been extremely well in all other respects during this entire
illness which is almost a year old. My family join me in very
best wishes for you and yours. Congratulations on your fine
results in Cuba.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, Albert E. Truby Albert E. Truby
/ Enclosure
P. S. I enjoyed and appreciated the many clippings you sent.
Dont you want them back?
